But what does [He]1485-the great man when [He]1485-the great man is about to give an order ? ' '[1485-the great man] [He]1485-the great man rubs the skin at the back of [his]1485-the great man neck - thus . Then falls one finger on the table and [He]1485-the great man makes a small sniffing noise through [his]1485-the great man nose . Then [He]1485-the great man speaks , saying : " Loose such and such a regiment . Call out such guns . " ' [The old man]861-the old man rose stiffly and saluted . '[1485-the great man] " For " ' - [Kim]344-kim translated into the vernacular the clinching sentences [he]344-kim had heard in [the dressing - room at [Umballa]52-umballa]5099-the dressing - room at umballa - '[1485-the great man] " For , " says [He]1485-the great man , " [we]1487-we should have done this long ago . ' Had [Kim]344-kim been at all [an ordinary boy]5106-an ordinary boy , [he]344-kim would have carried on the play ; but [one]1164-one does not know [Lahore city]939-lahore city , and least of all [the fakirs by [the Taksali Gate]5110-the taksali gate]5109-the fakirs by the taksali gate , for thirteen years without also knowing human nature . '[0-i] But [thou]1501-thy and [[thy]1501-thy husband]1502-thy husband hoped to get the cow cured for a handful of thanks . There is nothing else . '[5092-the old soldier] Here [the old soldier]5092-the old soldier bobbled up and asked if [Kim]344-kim would accept [his]344-kim hospitality for the night . '[861-the old man] Next morning [the priest]1044-the priest was in a very bad temper , but [the lama]868-the lama was quite happy ; and [Kim]344-kim had enjoyed a most interesting evening with [the old man]861-the old man , who brought out [his]861-the old man cavalry sabre and , balancing it on [his]861-the old man dry knees , told tales of [the Mutiny]1523-the mutiny and [young captains]1524-young captains thirty years in [[their]1524-young captains graves]1525-their graves , till [Kim]344-kim dropped off to sleep . '[1044-the priest] The first freshness of the day carried [the lama]868-the lama forward with long , easy , camel - like strides . Even the pony felt the good influence and almost broke into a trot as [Kim]344-kim laid a hand on the stirrup - leather . ' It repents [me]868-the lama that [I]868-the lama did not give a rupee to [the shrine]5151-the shrine , '[868-the lama] said [the lama]868-the lama on the last bead of [his]868-the lama eighty - one . '[868-the lama] ' It is not a good fancy , '[868-the lama] said [the lama]868-the lama . ' What profit to kill [men]752-men ? '[868-the lama] ' Very little - as [I]868-the lama know ; but if [evil men]5158-evil men were not now and then slain it would not be [a good world for [weaponless dreamers]5160-weaponless dreamers]5159-a good world for weaponless dreamers . '[868-the lama] ' What madness was that , then ? '[868-the lama] ' [The Gods , who sent it for a plague]5163-the gods , who sent it for a plague , alone know . A madness ate into all [the Army]88-the army , and [they]88-the army turned against [[their]88-the army officers]5164-their officers . That was the first evil , but not past remedy if [they]88-the army had then held [their]88-the army hands . But [they]88-the army chose to kill [[the Sahibs]5165-the sahibs '[868-the lama] wives]5166-the sahibs ' wives and [children]848-children . Then came [the Sahibs]5165-the sahibs from over [the sea]1554-the sea and called [them]5165-the sahibs to most strict account . ' '[5165-the sahibs] Some such rumour , [I]0-i believe , reached [me]0-i once long ago . [They]5165-the sahibs called it the Black Year , as [I]0-i remember . ' '[5165-the sahibs] What manner of life hast [thou]1555-thou led , not to know The Year ? A rumour indeed ! [All earth]1556-all earth knew , and trembled ! ' '[1557-our] [[Our]1557-our earth]1558-our earth never shook but once - upon the day that [the Excellent One]377-the excellent law received Enlightenment . ' '[377-the excellent law] Umph ! [I]0-i saw [Delhi]12-delhi shake at least- and [Delhi]12-delhi is [the navel of [the world]759-the world]1559-the navel of the world . ' '[0-i] So [they]5165-the sahibs turned against [women]4700-women and [children]848-children ? That was a bad deed , for which the punishment can not be avoided . ' '[1563-many] [Many]1563-many strove to do so , but with very small profit . [I]0-i was then in [a regiment of cavalry]1564-a regiment of cavalry . It broke . [Of six hundred and eighty sabres]1565-of six hundred and eighty sabres stood fast to [their]1565-of six hundred and eighty sabres salt - how many , think [you]1566-you ? Three . Of whom [I]0-i was [one]1164-one . ' '[1164-one] The greater merit . ' '[1164-one] Merit ! [We]1557-our did not consider it merit in those days . [[My]0-i people]1568-my people , [[my]0-i friends]1569-my friends , [[my]0-i brothers]1570-my brothers fell from [me]0-i . [They]5165-the sahibs said : " The time of [the English]1571-the english is accomplished . Let each strike out a little holding for [himself]1572-himself . " But [I]0-i had talked with [the men of [Sobraon]441-sobraon]1573-the men of sobraon , of [Chilianwallah]89-chilianwallah , of [Moodkee]90-moodkee and [Ferozeshah]442-ferozeshah . [I]0-i said : " Abide a little and the wind turns . There is no blessing in this work . " In those days [I]0-i rode seventy miles with [an English Memsahib]346-the english and [[her]1574-her babe]1575-her babe on [my]0-i saddle - bow . Wow ! That was a horse fit for [a man]750-a man ! [I]0-i placed [them]5165-the sahibs in safety , and back came [I]0-i to [[my]0-i officer]1577-my officer - [the one that was not killed of [[our]1579-our five]1580-our five]1578-the one that was not killed of our five . " Give [me]0-i work , " said [I]0-i , " for [I]0-i am [an outcast among [[my]0-i own kind]1582-my own kind]1581-an outcast among my own kind , and [[my]0-i cousin]1304-my cousin 's blood is wet on [my]0-i sabre . " " Be content , " said [he]1577-my officer . " There is great work forward . When this madness is over there is a recompense . " ' '[1577-my officer] Ay , there is a recompense when the madness is over , surely ? ' [the lama]868-the lama muttered half to [himself]868-the lama . '[1584-they] [They]1584-they did not hang medals in those days on [all who by accident had heard a gun fired]1585-all who by accident had heard a gun fired . No ! In nineteen pitched battles was [I]0-i ; in six- and - forty skirmishes of horse ; and in small affairs without number . Nine wounds [I]0-i bear ; a medal and four clasps and the medal of an Order , for [[my]0-i captains]1586-my captains , who are now [generals]1587-generals , remembered [me]0-i when [the Kaisar - i - Hind]443-the kaisar - i - hind had accomplished fifty years of [her]1588-her reign , and all [the land]4998-the land rejoiced . [They]1584-they said : " Give [him]1577-my officer the Order of [Berittish India]91-berittish india . " [I]0-i carry it upon [my]0-i neck now . ' '[1594-we] And after ? ' said [the lama]868-the lama . '[1594-we] Oh , afterwards [they]1584-they go away , but not before [[my]0-i village]1596-my village has seen . [I]0-i have never pestered [Them]1244-the gods with prayers . [I]0-i do not think [They]1244-the gods will pester [me]0-i . Look [you]1599-you , [I]0-i have noticed in [my]0-i long life that [those who eternally break in upon Those Above with complaints and reports and bellowings and weepings]1600-those who eternally break in upon those above with complaints and reports and bellowings and weepings are presently sent for in haste , as [[our]1594-we Colonel]1601-our colonel used to send for [slack - jawed down - country men who talked too much]1602-slack - jawed down - country men who talked too much . No , [I]0-i have never wearied [the Gods]402-the gods . [They]1244-the gods will remember this , and give [me]0-i a quiet place where [I]0-i can drive [my]0-i lance in the shade , and wait to welcome [[my]0-i sons]1474-my sons : [I]0-i have no less than [three Rissaldar - majors all - in [the regiments]1605-the regiments]1604-three rissaldar - majors all - in the regiments . ' '[1604-three rissaldar - majors all - in the regiments] And [they]1604-three rissaldar - majors all - in the regiments likewise , bound upon the Wheel , go forth from life to life - from despair to despair , ' said the lama below [his]0-i breath , '[1604-three rissaldar - majors all - in the regiments] hot , uneasy , snatching . Well , well , [my]0-i holding can pay for all . How thinkest [thou]1611-thou ? It is a well - watered strip , but [[my]0-i men]1048-my men cheat [me]0-i . [I]0-i do not know how to ask save at the lance 's point . Ugh ! [I]0-i grow angry and [I]0-i curse [them]1048-my men , and [they]1048-my men feign penitence , but behind [my]0-i back [I]0-i know [they]1048-my men call [me]0-i [a toothless old ape]1613-a toothless old ape . ' '[1048-my men] Hast [thou]1611-thou never desired any other thing ? ' '[1048-my men] Yes - yes - a thousand times ! ' '[1616-she] That strength is weakness . ' '[1616-she] It has turned so ; but fifty years since [I]0-i could have proved it otherwise , ' [the old soldier]5092-the old soldier retorted , driving [his]5092-the old soldier stirrup - edge into the pony 's lean flank . '[0-i] But [I]0-i know [a River of great healing]1615-a river of great healing . ' '[0-i] [I]0-i have drank Gunga - water to the edge of dropsy . [I]0-i do not know [thy]1611-thou life , but [thy]1611-thou face is the face of [the honourable and courteous]1619-the honourable and courteous . Enter now upon [the Middle Way which is the path to Freedom]1620-the middle way which is the path to freedom . Hear the Most Excellent Law , and do not follow dreams . ' '[1240-old man] Speak , then , [old man]1240-old man , ' [the soldier]1204-the soldier smiled , half saluting . '[1240-old man] [We]1622-we be [all babblers]1623-all babblers at [our]1622-we age . ' [The lama]868-the lama squatted under the shade of a mango , whose shadow played checkerwise over [his]868-the lama face ; [the soldier]1204-the soldier sat stiffly on the pony ; and [Kim]344-kim , making sure that there were no snakes , lay down in the crotch of the twisted roots . There was a drowsy buzz of small life in hot sunshine , a cooing of doves , and a sleepy drone of well - wheels across [the fields]4992-the fields . Slowly and impressively [the lama]868-the lama began . At the end of ten minutes [the old soldier]5092-the old soldier slid from [his]5092-the old soldier pony , to hear better as [he]5092-the old soldier said , and sat with the reins round [his]5092-the old soldier wrist . [The lama]868-the lama 's voice faltered , the periods lengthened . [Kim]344-kim was busy watching a grey squirrel . When the little scolding bunch of fur , close pressed to the branch , disappeared , [preacher]5178-preacher and [audience]5179-audience were fast asleep , [the old officer]5180-the old officer 's strong - cut head pillowed on [his]5092-the old soldier arm , [the lama]868-the lama 's thrown back against the tree - bole , where it showed like yellow ivory . [A naked child]5182-a naked child toddled up , stared , and , moved by some quick impulse of reverence , made a solemn little obeisance before [the lama]868-the lama - only [the child]747-the child was so short and fat that [it]747-the child toppled over sideways , and [Kim]344-kim laughed at the sprawling , chubby legs . '[1240-old man] What is it ? What orders ? ... It is ... [a child]4501-a child ! [I]0-i dreamed it was an alarm . [Little one - little one]1625-little one - little one - do not cry . Have [I]0-i slept ? That was discourteous indeed ! ' '[0-i] [I]0-i fear ! [I]0-i am afraid ! ' roared [the child]747-the child . '[0-i] What is it to fear ? [Two old men]1626-two old men and [a boy]4870-a boy ? How wilt [thou]1628-thou ever make [a soldier]1629-a soldier , [Princeling]1630-princeling ? '[1652-lances of the north] It is long since [I]0-i have ridden this way , but [[thy]1654-thy boy]1655-thy boy 's talk stirred [me]0-i . See , [Holy One]385-holy one - [the Great Road which is the backbone of all [Hind]70-hind]1656-the great road which is the backbone of all hind . For the most part [it]1656-the great road which is the backbone of all hind is shaded , as here , with four lines of trees ; [the middle road]1657-the middle road - all hard - takes the quick traffic . In the days before [rail - carriages]1658-rail - carriages [the Sahibs]5165-the sahibs travelled up and down here in hundreds . Now there are only [country - carts]1660-country - carts and such like . Left and right is [the rougher road]1661-the rougher road for [the heavy carts]1662-the heavy carts - grain and cotton and timber , fodder , lime and hides . [A man]750-a man goes in safety here for at every few koss is [a police - station]1664-a police - station . [The police]1665-the police are [thieves]4667-thieves and [extortioners]1667-extortioners [I]0-i [myself]0-i would patrol [it]1656-the great road which is the backbone of all hind with cavalry - [young recruits under [a strong captain]1669-a strong captain]1668-young recruits under a strong captain , but at least [they]1668-young recruits under a strong captain do not suffer any rivals . [Brahmins]5204-brahmins and [chumars]5205-chumars , [bankers and tinkers]5206-bankers and tinkers , [barbers and bunnias]5207-barbers and bunnias , [pilgrims]1118-pilgrims and [potters]5209-potters - all [the world]759-the world going and coming . '[752-men] And truly [the Grand Trunk Road]5057-the grand trunk road is a wonderful spectacle . [It]5057-the grand trunk road runs straight , bearing without crowding [India]8-india 's traffic for fifteen hundred miles - such a river of life as nowhere else exists in [the world]759-the world . '[1677-a constable] The voice and a venomous whip - cracking came out of a pillar of dust fifty yards away , where a cart had broken down . [We]1711-us brought the news bear witness , [we]1711-us brought the news , and now [we]1711-us go . ' [Kim]344-kim half - crooked [his]344-kim hand at [his]344-kim side . [The son]5242-the son tossed a silver coin through the sunlight , grumbling something about [beggars]4999-beggars and [jugglers]5147-jugglers . It was a four - anna piece , and would feed [them]4999-beggars well for days . [The lama , seeing the flash of the metal]5245-the lama , seeing the flash of the metal , droned a blessing . '[1709-thou] Go [thy]1709-thou way , [Friend of all [the World]14-the world]1716-friend of all the world , ' piped [the old soldier]5092-the old soldier , wheeling [his]0-i scrawny mount . '[1709-thou] For once in all [my]0-i days [I]0-i have met [a true prophet]1717-a true prophet - who was not in [the Army]88-the army . ' [Father]452-father victor and [son]1693-son swung round together : [the old man]861-the old man sitting as erect as [the younger]5249-the younger . [A Punjabi constable in yellow linen trousers slouched across [the road]4566-the road]5250-a punjabi constable in yellow linen trousers slouched across the road . [He]5250-a punjabi constable in yellow linen trousers slouched across the road had seen the money pass . '[1717-a true prophet] Halt ! ' [he]5250-a punjabi constable in yellow linen trousers slouched across the road cried in impressive English . '[1717-a true prophet] Know [ye]1718-ye not that there is [a takkus of two annas]1719-a takkus of two annas a head , which is four annas , on those who enter [the Road]4566-the road from [this side - road]1721-this side - road ? It is the order of [the Sirkar]405-the sirkar , and the money is spent for the planting of trees and the beautification of the ways . ' '[1665-the police] And the bellies of [the police]1665-the police , ' said [Kim]344-kim , slipping out of arm 's reach . '[1723-man with a mud head] Consider for a while , [man with a mud head]1723-man with a mud head . Think [you]1723-man with a mud head [we]1724-we came from [the nearest pond]1725-the nearest pond like the frog , [[thy]1723-man with a mud head father - in - law]1726-thy father - in - law ? Hast [thou]1723-man with a mud head ever heard the name of [[thy]1723-man with a mud head brother]1727-thy brother ? ' '[1723-man with a mud head] And who was [he]1727-thy brother ? Leave [the boy]986-the boy alone , ' cried [a senior constable]5252-a senior constable , immensely delighted , as [he]5252-a senior constable squatted down to smoke [his]5252-a senior constable pipe in [the veranda]765-the veranda . '[1727-thy brother] [He]1727-thy brother took a label from a bottle of belaitee - pani soda - water , and , affixing it to [a bridge]1729-a bridge , collected taxes for a month from [those who passed]1730-those who passed , saying that it was [the Sirkar]405-the sirkar 's order . Then came [an Englishman]1107-an englishman and broke [his]1107-an englishman head . Ah , [brother]5021-brother , [I]0-i am a town - crow , not [a village]1733-a village - crow ! ' [The policeman]4469-the policeman drew back abashed , and [Kim]344-kim hooted at [him]4469-the policeman all down [the road]4566-the road . '[0-i] Was there ever such [a disciple]4651-a disciple as [I]0-i ? ' [he]0-i cried merrily to [the lama]868-the lama . '[4651-a disciple] [All earth]1556-all earth would have picked [thy]0-i bones within ten mile of [Lahore city]939-lahore city if [I]0-i had not guarded [thee]0-i . ' '[0-i] [I]0-i consider in [my]0-i own mind whether [thou]0-i art a spirit , sometimes , or sometimes an evil imp , ' said [the lama]868-the lama , smiling slowly . '[0-i] [I]0-i am [[thy]0-i chela]1737-thy chela . ' [Kim]344-kim dropped into step at [his]0-i side - that indescribable gait of the long - distance tramp all [the world over]5258-the world over . '[0-i] Now let [us]1738-they walk , ' muttered [the lama]868-the lama , and to the click of [his]868-the lama rosary [they]1738-they walked in silence mile upon mile . [The lama as usual]5260-the lama as usual , was deep in meditation , but [Kim]344-kim 's bright eyes were open wide . This broad , smiling river of life , [he]344-kim considered , was a vast improvement on [the cramped and crowded Lahore streets]5261-the cramped and crowded lahore streets . There were [new people]1274-new people and new sights at every stride - castes [he]344-kim knew and castes that were altogether out of [his]344-kim experience . [They]1738-they met [a troop of long - haired , strong - scented Sansis with baskets of lizards and other unclean food on [their]5263-a troop of long - haired , strong - scented sansis with baskets of lizards and other unclean food on their backs , their lean dogs sniffing at their heels backs , [their]5263-a troop of long - haired , strong - scented sansis with baskets of lizards and other unclean food on their backs , their lean dogs sniffing at their heels lean dogs sniffing at [their]5263-a troop of long - haired , strong - scented sansis with baskets of lizards and other unclean food on their backs , their lean dogs sniffing at their heels heels]5263-a troop of long - haired , strong - scented sansis with baskets of lizards and other unclean food on their backs , their lean dogs sniffing at their heels . [These people]5126-these people kept [their]5126-these people own side of [the road]4566-the road '[0-i] , moving at a quick , furtive jog - trot , and [all other castes]1739-all other castes gave [them]1739-all other castes ample room ; for [the Sansi]453-the sansi is deep pollution . Behind [them]1740-they , walking wide and stiffly across the strong shadows , the memory of [his]1741-his leg - irons still on [him]1741-his , strode [one newly released from [the jail]1743-the jail]1742-one newly released from the jail ; [his]1741-his full stomach and shiny skin to prove that [the Government]852-the government fed [[its]852-the government prisoners]1745-its prisoners better than [most honest men]1746-most honest men could feed [themselves]1746-most honest men . [Kim]344-kim knew that walk well , and made broad jest of it as [they]1740-they passed . Then an [Akali]454-akali , [a wild - eyed , wild - haired Sikh devotee in the blue - checked clothes of [his]454-akali faith]1747-a wild - eyed , wild - haired sikh devotee in the blue - checked clothes of his faith , with polished - steel quoits glistening on the cone of [his]454-akali tall blue turban , stalked past , returning from a visit to one of [the independent Sikh States]1748-the independent sikh states , where [he]454-akali had been singing the ancient glories of [the Khalsa]455-the khalsa to [College - trained princelings in top - boots and white - cord breeches]1749-college - trained princelings in top - boots and white - cord breeches . [Kim]344-kim was careful not to irritate [that man]4846-that man ; for [the Akali]454-akali 's temper is short and [his]454-akali arm quick . Here and there [they]1740-they met or were overtaken by the gaily dressed crowds of [whole villages]1751-whole villages turning out to some local fair ; [the women]781-the women , with [their]781-the women babes on [their]781-the women hips , walking behind [the men]5050-the men , [the older boys]1754-the older boys prancing on sticks of sugar - cane , dragging rude brass models of locomotives such as [they]1754-the older boys sell for a halfpenny , or flashing the sun into the eyes of [[their]1754-the older boys betters]1755-their betters from cheap toy mirrors . [One]1164-one could see at a glance what [each]1757-each had bought ; and if there were any doubt it needed only to watch [the wives]1758-the wives comparing , brown arm against brown arm , the newly purchased dull glass bracelets that come from [the North - West]93-the north - west . [These merry - makers]1759-these merry - makers stepped slowly , calling one to the other and stopping to haggle with [sweetmeat - sellers]1760-sweetmeat - sellers , or to make a prayer before one of the wayside shrines - sometimes [Hindu]386-little hindu , sometimes [Mussalman]456-mussalman - which [the low - caste of both creeds]1761-the low - caste of both creeds share with beautiful impartiality . A solid line of blue , rising and falling like the back of a caterpillar in haste , would swing up through the quivering dust and trot past to a chorus of quick cackling . That was [a gang of [changars]1763-changars]1762-a gang of changars - [the women who have taken [all the embankments of all the Northern railways under [their]1764-the women who have taken all the embankments of all the northern railways under their charge charge]1765-all the embankments of all the northern railways under their charge]1764-the women who have taken all the embankments of all the northern railways under their charge - [a flat - footed , big - bosomed , strong - limbed , blue - petticoated clan of earth - carriers , hurrying north on news of a job]1766-a flat - footed , big - bosomed , strong - limbed , blue - petticoated clan of earth - carriers , hurrying north on news of a job , and wasting no time by [the road]4566-the road . [They]1762-a gang of changars belong to [the caste whose [men]752-men do not count]1768-the caste whose men do not count , and [they]1762-a gang of changars walked with squared elbows , swinging hips , and heads on high , as suits [women who carry heavy weights]1770-women who carry heavy weights . A little later [a marriage procession]1771-a marriage procession would strike into [the Grand Trunk]1772-the grand trunk with music and shoutings , and a smell of marigold and jasmine stronger even than the reek of the dust . [One]1164-one could see [the bride]1774-the bride 's litter , a blur of red and tinsel , staggering through the haze , while [the bridegroom]1775-the bridegroom 's bewreathed pony turned aside to snatch a mouthful from [a passing fodder - cart]1776-a passing fodder - cart . Then [Kim]344-kim would join the Kentish - fire of good wishes and bad jokes , wishing [the couple]1777-the couple [a hundred sons]1778-a hundred sons and [no daughters]1779-no daughters , as the saying is . Still more interesting and more to be shouted over it was when [a strolling juggler with some half - trained monkeys]1780-a strolling juggler with some half - trained monkeys , or a panting , feeble bear , or [a woman who tied goats ' horns to [her]5267-her feet , and with these danced on a slack - rope , set the horses to shying and [the women to shrill , long - drawn quavers of amazement]5268-the women to shrill , long - drawn quavers of amazement]5266-a woman who tied goats ' horns to her feet , and with these danced on a slack - rope , set the horses to shying and the women to shrill , long - drawn quavers of amazement . [The lama]868-the lama never raised [his]868-the lama eyes . [He]868-the lama did not note [the money - lender on [his]868-the lama goose - rumped pony , hastening along to collect the cruel interest]5270-the money - lender on his goose - rumped pony , hastening along to collect the cruel interest ; or [the long - shouting , deep - voiced little mob -still in military formation - of [native soldiers on leave]5272-native soldiers on leave , rejoicing to be rid of [their]5272-native soldiers on leave breeches and puttees , and saying the most outrageous things to [the most respectable women in sight]5273-the most respectable women in sight]5271-the long - shouting , deep - voiced little mob -still in military formation - of native soldiers on leave , rejoicing to be rid of their breeches and puttees , and saying the most outrageous things to the most respectable women in sight . Even [the seller of Ganges]5274-the seller of ganges - water [he]868-the lama did not see , and [Kim]344-kim expected that [he]868-the lama would at least buy a bottle of that precious stuff . [He]344-kim looked steadily at [the ground]1001-the ground , and strode as steadily hour after hour , [his]344-kim soul busied elsewhere . But [Kim]344-kim was in the seventh heaven of joy . [The Grand Trunk]94-the grand trunk at this point was built on an embankment to guard against winter floods from [the foothills]5276-the foothills , so that [one]1164-one walked , as it were , a little above [the country]806-the country , along [a stately corridor]5279-a stately corridor , seeing all [India]8-india spread out to left and right . It was beautiful to behold [the many - yoked grain and cotton wagons]5280-the many - yoked grain and cotton wagons crawling over [the country roads]5281-the country roads : [one]1164-one could hear [their]5280-the many - yoked grain and cotton wagons axles , complaining a mile away , coming nearer , till with shouts and yells and bad words [they]5280-the many - yoked grain and cotton wagons climbed up the steep incline and plunged on to [the hard main road]5283-the hard main road , carter reviling carter . It was equally beautiful to watch [the people]4594-the people , little clumps of red and blue and pink and white and saffron , turning aside to go to [[their]4594-the people own villages]5285-their own villages , dispersing and growing small by twos and threes across [the level plain]5286-the level plain . [Kim]344-kim felt these things , though [he]344-kim could not give tongue to [his]344-kim feelings , and so contented [himself]344-kim with buying peeled sugar - cane and spitting the pith generously about [his]344-kim path . From time to time [the lama]868-the lama took snuff , and at last [Kim]344-kim could endure the silence no longer . '[5266-a woman who tied goats ' horns to her feet , and with these danced on a slack - rope , set the horses to shying and the women to shrill , long - drawn quavers of amazement] This is [a good land]1781-a good land - [the land of [the South]1783-the south]1782-the land of the south ! ' said [he]344-kim . '[5266-a woman who tied goats ' horns to her feet , and with these danced on a slack - rope , set the horses to shying and the women to shrill , long - drawn quavers of amazement] The air is good ; the water is good . Eh ? ' '[5266-a woman who tied goats ' horns to her feet , and with these danced on a slack - rope , set the horses to shying and the women to shrill , long - drawn quavers of amazement] And [they]1784-they are all bound upon the Wheel , ' said [the lama]868-the lama . '[1784-they] Bound from life after life . To none of these has the Way been shown . ' [He]868-the lama shook [himself]868-the lama back to [this world]1066-this world . '[5266-a woman who tied goats ' horns to her feet , and with these danced on a slack - rope , set the horses to shying and the women to shrill , long - drawn quavers of amazement] And now [we]1785-we have walked a weary way , ' said [Kim]344-kim . '[5266-a woman who tied goats ' horns to her feet , and with these danced on a slack - rope , set the horses to shying and the women to shrill , long - drawn quavers of amazement] Surely [we]1785-we shall soon come to a parao a resting - place . Shall [we]1785-we stay there ? Look , the sun is sloping . ' '[5266-a woman who tied goats ' horns to her feet , and with these danced on a slack - rope , set the horses to shying and the women to shrill , long - drawn quavers of amazement] Who will receive [us]1785-we this evening ? ' '[5266-a woman who tied goats ' horns to her feet , and with these danced on a slack - rope , set the horses to shying and the women to shrill , long - drawn quavers of amazement] That is all one . [This country]5119-this country is full of [good folk]1787-good folk . Besides ' [he]868-the lama sunk [his]868-the lama voice beneath a whisper - '[5266-a woman who tied goats ' horns to her feet , and with these danced on a slack - rope , set the horses to shying and the women to shrill , long - drawn quavers of amazement] [we]1785-we have money . ' [The crowd]4816-the crowd thickened as [they]1785-we neared the resting - place which marked the end of [their]1785-we day 's journey . [A line of stalls]5291-a line of stalls selling very simple food and tobacco , a stack of firewood , [a police - station]1664-a police - station , [a well]5293-a well , [a horse - trough]5294-a horse - trough , a few trees , and , under [them]5291-a line of stalls , some trampled ground dotted with the black ashes of old fires , are all that mark a parao on the [Grand Trunk]94-the grand trunk ; if [you]5295-you except [the beggars]5296-the beggars and the crows - both hungry . By this time the sun was driving broad golden spokes through the lower branches of the mango - trees ; the parakeets and doves were coming . [home]743-home in [their]743-home hundreds ; [the chattering , grey - backed Seven Sisters , talking over the day]5298-the chattering , grey - backed seven sisters , talking over the day 's adventures , walked back and forth in twos and threes almost under the feet of [the travellers]4835-the travellers ; and shufflings and scufflings in the branches showed that the bats were ready to go out on the night - picket . Swiftly the light gathered itself together , painted for an instant the faces and the cartwheels and the bullocks '[5266-a woman who tied goats ' horns to her feet , and with these danced on a slack - rope , set the horses to shying and the women to shrill , long - drawn quavers of amazement] horns as red as blood . Then the night fell , changing the touch of the air , drawing a low , even haze , like a gossamer veil of blue , across the face of [the country]806-the country , and bringing out , keen and distinct , the smell of wood - smoke and cattle and the good scent of wheaten cakes cooked on ashes . [The evening patrol]1789-the evening patrol hurried out of [the police - station]1790-the police - station with important coughings and reiterated orders ; and a live charcoal ball in the cup of [a wayside carter]1791-a wayside carter 's hookah glowed red while [Kim]344-kim 's eye mechanically watched the last flicker of the sun on the brass tweezers . The life of [the parao]1792-the parao was very like that of [the Kashmir Serai]43-the kashmir serai on a small scale . [Kim]344-kim dived into [the happy Asiatic]1793-the happy asiatic disorder which , if [you]1794-you only allow time , will bring [you]1794-you everything that [a simple man]1795-a simple man needs . [His]344-kim wants were few , because , since [the lama]868-the lama had no caste scruples , cooked food from [the nearest stall]1797-the nearest stall would serve ; but , for luxury 's sake , [Kim]344-kim bought a handful of dung - cakes to build a fire . All about , coming and going round the little flames , [men]752-men cried for oil , or grain , or sweetmeats , or tobacco , jostling [one another]4533-one another while [they]752-men waited [their]752-men turn at [the well]1800-the well ; and under [the men]5050-the men 's voices [you]1794-you heard from [halted , shuttered carts]1802-halted , shuttered carts the high squeals and giggles of [women whose faces should not be seen in public]1803-women whose faces should not be seen in public . Nowadays , [well - educated natives]1804-well - educated natives are of opinion that when [[their]1804-well - educated natives womenfolk]1805-their womenfolk travel - and [they]1804-well - educated natives visit a good deal - it is better to take [them]1805-their womenfolk quickly by rail in [a properly screened compartment]1806-a properly screened compartment ; and that custom is spreading . But there are always [those of the old rock who hold by the use of [[their]1807-those of the old rock who hold by the use of their forefathers forefathers]1808-their forefathers]1807-those of the old rock who hold by the use of their forefathers ; and , above all , there are always [the old women]1809-the old women - more conservative than [the men]5050-the men - who toward the end of [their]1809-the old women days go on a pilgrimage . [They]1809-the old women , being withered and undesirable , do not , under certain circumstances , object to unveiling . After [their]1809-the old women long seclusion , during which [they]1809-the old women have always been in business touch with a thousand outside interests , [they]1809-the old women love the bustle and stir of [the open road]1811-the open road , the gatherings at [the shrines]1812-the shrines , and the infinite possibilities of gossip with [like - minded dowagers]1813-like - minded dowagers . Very often it suits [a longsuffering family]1814-a longsuffering family that [a strong - tongued , iron - willed old lady]1815-a strong - tongued , iron - willed old lady should disport [herself]1815-a strong - tongued , iron - willed old lady about [India]8-india in this fashion ; for certainly pilgrimage is grateful to [the Gods]1244-the gods . So all about [India]8-india , in [the most remote places]1817-the most remote places , as in the most public , [you]1818-you find [some knot of grizzled servitors in nominal charge of [an old lady who is more or less curtained and hid away in [a bullock - cart]1821-a bullock - cart]1820-an old lady who is more or less curtained and hid away in a bullock - cart]1819-some knot of grizzled servitors in nominal charge of an old lady who is more or less curtained and hid away in a bullock - cart . [Such men]1822-such men are staid and discreet , and when [a European]1823-a european or [a high - caste native]1824-a high - caste native is near will net [their]1822-such men charge with most elaborate precautions ; but in the ordinary haphazard chances of pilgrimage the precautions are not taken . [The old lady]1825-the old lady is , after all , intensely human , and lives to look upon life . [Kim]344-kim marked down a gaily ornamented ruth or [family bullock - cart]1826-family bullock - cart , with a broidered canopy of two domes , like a double - humped camel , which had just been drawn into the par . [Eight men]1827-eight men made its retinue , and two of the eight were armed with rusty sabres - sure signs that [they]1822-such men followed [a person of distinction]1828-a person of distinction , for [the common folk]1829-the common folk do not bear arms . An increasing cackle of complaints , orders , and jests , and what to [a European]1823-a european would have been bad language , came from behind the curtains . Here was evidently [a woman used to command]1831-a woman used to command . [Kim]344-kim looked over [the retinue]1832-the retinue critically . [Half of [them]1832-the retinue]1833-half of them were [thin- legged , grey - bearded Ooryas from [down country]1835-down country]1834-thin- legged , grey - bearded ooryas from down country . [The other half]1836-the other half were [duffle - clad , felt - hatted hillmen of [the North]48-the north]1837-duffle - clad , felt - hatted hillmen of the north ; and that mixture told [its]1838-its own tale , even if [he]344-kim had not overheard the incessant sparring between the two divisions . [The old lady]1825-the old lady was going [south]1840-south on a visit - probably to [a rich relative]1841-a rich relative , most probably to [a son - in- law]1842-a son - in- law , who had sent up [an escort as a mark of respect]1843-an escort as a mark of respect . [The hillmen]1844-the hillmen would be of [[her]1825-the old lady own people]1845-her own people - [Kulu]19-kulu or [Kangra folk]1846-kangra folk . It was quite clear that [she]1825-the old lady was not taking [[her]1825-the old lady daughter]1847-her daughter down to be wedded , or the curtains would have been laced [home]743-home and [the guard]4805-the guard would have allowed [no one]786-no one near [the car]1851-the car . [A merry and a high - spirited dame]1852-a merry and a high - spirited dame , thought [Kim]344-kim , balancing the dung - cake in one hand , the cooked food in the other , and piloting [the lama]868-the lama with a nudging shoulder . Something might be made out of the meeting . [The lama]868-the lama would give [him]868-the lama no help , but , as [a conscientious chela]1855-a conscientious chela , [Kim]344-kim was delighted to beg for two . [He]344-kim built [his]344-kim fire as close to [the cart]1856-the cart as [he]344-kim dared , waiting for one of [the escort]1857-the escort to order [him]868-the lama away . [The lama]868-the lama dropped wearily to the ground , much as a heavy fruit - eating bat cowers , and returned to [his]868-the lama rosary . ' Stand farther off , [beggar]5300-beggar ! '[344-kim] The order was shouted in broken [Hindustani]77-hindustani by [one of [the hillmen]1844-the hillmen]1859-one of the hillmen . ' Huh ! It is only [a pahari]5301-a pahari [a hillman]834-a hillman '[344-kim] , said [Kim]344-kim over [his]344-kim shoulder . ' Since when have [the hill - asses]5303-the hill - asses owned all [Hindustan]92-hindustan ? '[344-kim] The retort was a swift and brilliant sketch of [Kim]344-kim 's pedigree for three generations . ' Ah ! '[344-kim] [Kim]344-kim 's voice was sweeter than ever , as [he]344-kim broke the dung - cake into fit pieces . ' In [[my]344-kim country]5304-my country [we]5305-we call that the beginning of love - talk . '[344-kim] A harsh , thin cackle behind the curtains put [the hillman]1861-the hillman on [his]1861-the hillman mettle for a second shot . ' Not so bad - not so bad , '[344-kim] said [Kim]344-kim with calm . ' But have a care , [[my]344-kim brother]4548-my brother , lest [we]5305-we - [we]5305-we , [I]344-kim say - be minded to give a curse or so in return . And [our]5305-we curses have the knack of biting [home]743-home . '[344-kim] [The Ooryas]459-the ooryas laughed ; [the hillman]1861-the hillman sprang forward threateningly . [The lama]868-the lama suddenly raised [his]868-the lama head , bringing [his]868-the lama huge tam - o'-shanter hat into the full light of [Kim]344-kim 's new - started fire . ' What is it ? '[868-the lama] said [he]868-the lama . [The man]4471-the man halted as though struck to stone . ' [I]4471-the man - [I]4471-the man - am saved from a great sin , '[4471-the man] [he]4471-the man stammered . ' [The foreigner]5308-the foreigner has found [him]868-the lama [a priest]820-a priest at last , '[1865-one of the ooryas] whispered [one of [the Ooryas]459-the ooryas]1865-one of the ooryas . ' [Hai]444-hai ! Why is that beggar - brat not well beaten ? '[1866-the old woman] [the old woman]1866-the old woman cried . [The hillman]1861-the hillman drew back to the cart and whispered something to the curtain . There was dead silence , then a muttering . ' This goes well , '[344-kim] thought [Kim]344-kim , pretending neither to see nor hear . ' When - when - [he]868-the lama has eaten '[1861-the hillman] - [the hillman]1861-the hillman fawned on [Kim]344-kim - ' it - it is requested that [the Holy One]4553-the holy one will do the honour to talk to one who would speak to [him]868-the lama . '[1861-the hillman] ' After [he]868-the lama has eaten [he]868-the lama will sleep , '[344-kim] [Kim]344-kim returned loftily . [He]344-kim could not quite see what new turn the game had taken , but stood resolute to profit by it . ' Now [I]1861-the hillman will get [him]868-the lama [his]868-the lama food . '[1861-the hillman] The last sentence , spoken loudly , ended with a sigh as of faintness . ' [I]1861-the hillman - [I]1861-the hillman [myself]1861-the hillman and [the others of [[my]1861-the hillman people]1568-my people]5311-the others of my people will look to that - if it is permitted . '[1861-the hillman] ' It is permitted , '[344-kim] said [Kim]344-kim , more loftily than ever . ' [Holy One]385-holy one , [these people]5126-these people will bring [us]5314-us food . '[344-kim] ' [The land]4998-the land is good . [All the country of [the South]74-the south]5316-all the country of the south is good - [a great and a terrible world]5317-a great and a terrible world , '[868-the lama] mumbled [the lama]868-the lama drowsily . ' Let [him]868-the lama sleep , '[344-kim] said [Kim]344-kim , ' but look to it that [we]5314-us are well fed when [he]868-the lama wakes . [He]868-the lama is [a very holy man]4878-a very holy man . '[344-kim] Again [one of [the Ooryas]459-the ooryas]1865-one of the ooryas said something contemptuously . ' [He]868-the lama is [not a fakir]5319-not a fakir . [He]868-the lama is not [a down - country beggar]5320-a down - country beggar , '[344-kim] [Kim]344-kim went on severely , addressing the stars . ' [He]868-the lama is [the most holy of holy men]5321-the most holy of holy men . [He]868-the lama is above [all castes]4464-all castes . [I]344-kim am [his]868-the lama chela . '[344-kim] ' Come here ! '[1871-the flat thin voice behind the curtain] said [the flat thin voice behind the curtain]1871-the flat thin voice behind the curtain ; and [Kim]344-kim came , conscious that eyes [he]344-kim could not see were staring at [him]344-kim . One skinny brown finger heavy with rings lay on the edge of [the cart]1856-the cart , and the talk went this way : ' Who is [that one]5323-that one ? '[1871-the flat thin voice behind the curtain] ' [An exceedingly holy one]5324-an exceedingly holy one . [He]5324-an exceedingly holy one comes from [far off]5325-far off . [He]5324-an exceedingly holy one comes from [Tibet]22-tibet . '[344-kim] ' Where in [Tibet]22-tibet ? '[344-kim] ' From behind [the snows]5326-the snows - from [a very far place]5327-a very far place . [He]5324-an exceedingly holy one knows the stars ; [he]5324-an exceedingly holy one makes horoscopes ; [he]5324-an exceedingly holy one reads nativities . But [he]5324-an exceedingly holy one does not do this for money . [He]5324-an exceedingly holy one does it for kindness and great charity . [I]344-kim am [[his]5324-an exceedingly holy one disciple]949-his disciple . [I]344-kim am called also [the Friend of [the Stars]438-the stars]1491-the friend of the stars . '[344-kim] ' [Thou]344-kim art [no hillman]5330-no hillman . '[1871-the flat thin voice behind the curtain] ' Ask [him]5324-an exceedingly holy one . [Lamas]461-lamas [I]344-kim know , and to these [I]344-kim give reverence , but [thou]344-kim art no more a lawful chela than this [my]344-kim finger is the pole of [this wagon]5334-this wagon . [Thou]344-kim art [a casteless Hindu]5335-a casteless hindu - [a bold and unblushing beggar]5336-a bold and unblushing beggar , attached , belike , to [the Holy One]385-holy one for the sake of gain . '[344-kim] ' Do [we]5337-we not all work for gain ? '[344-kim] [Kim]344-kim changed [his]344-kim tone promptly to match that altered voice . ' [I]344-kim have heard '[344-kim] - this was a bow drawn at a venture - ' [I]344-kim have heard - '[344-kim] ' What hast [thou]344-kim heard ? '[1873-she] [she]1873-she snapped , rapping with the finger . ' Nothing that [I]1873-she well remember , but some talk in [the bazars]5338-the bazars , which is doubtless a lie , that [even Rajahs]5339-even rajahs - small [Hill Rajahs]408-rajahs - '[1873-she] ' But none the less of [good Rajput blood]5340-good rajput blood . '[344-kim] ' Assuredly of good blood . That these even sell the more comely of [[their]408-rajahs womenfolk]1805-their womenfolk for gain . '[1873-she] If there be one thing in [the world]759-the world that [the small Hill Rajahs]408-rajahs deny it is just this charge ; but it happens to be one thing that [the bazars]5338-the bazars believe , when [they]5338-the bazars discuss [the mysterious slave - traffics of [India]8-india]1876-the mysterious slave - traffics of india . [The old lady]1825-the old lady explained to [Kim]344-kim , in a tense , indignant whisper , precisely what manner and fashion of malignant liar [he]344-kim was . Had [Kim]344-kim hinted this when [she]1825-the old lady was [a girl]1878-a girl , [he]344-kim would have been pommelled to death that same evening by an elephant . This was perfectly true . ' Ahai ! [I]344-kim am only [a beggar 's brat]5345-a beggar 's brat , as [the Eye of Beauty]5346-the eye of beauty has said , '[344-kim] [he]344-kim wailed in extravagant terror . ' Eye of [Beauty]462-beauty , forsooth ! Who am [I]344-kim that [thou]5347-thou shouldst fling beggar - endearments at [me]344-kim ? '[344-kim] And yet [she]1825-the old lady laughed at the long- forgotten word . ' Forty years ago that might have been said , and not without truth . Ay . thirty years ago . '[1825-the old lady] ' [Great Queen]463-great queen , '[344-kim] said [Kim]344-kim promptly , for [he]344-kim heard [her]1825-the old lady shaking with indignation , ' [I]1825-the old lady am even what [the Great Queen]5352-the great queen says [I]1825-the old lady am ; but none the less is [[my]1825-the old lady master]1715-my master holy . '[1825-the old lady] ' Pity [my]1825-the old lady stupidity . [I]1825-the old lady thought it was given as an order - '[1825-the old lady] ' It was not . It was a petition . Does this make all clear ? '[1825-the old lady] A silver coin clicked on the edge of the cart . [Kim]344-kim took it and salaamed profoundly . ' [I]1825-the old lady am but [the Holy One 's disciple]5357-the holy one 's disciple . When [he]868-the lama has eaten perhaps [he]868-the lama will come . '[1825-the old lady] ' Oh , [villain and shameless rogue]5358-villain and shameless rogue ! '[1825-the old lady] The jewelled forefinger shook itself at [him]344-kim reprovingly ; but [he]344-kim could hear [the old lady]1825-the old lady 's chuckle . ' Nay , what is it ? '[344-kim] [he]344-kim said , dropping into [his]344-kim most caressing and confidential tone - the one , [he]344-kim well knew , that [few]1882-few could resist . ' Is - is there any need of [a son in [thy]1825-the old lady family]5359-a son in thy family ? Moreover , [[my]1825-the old lady daughter]4623-my daughter has borne [[her]4623-my daughter man]5231-her man - child . '[1825-the old lady] ' Two arrows in the quiver are better than one ; and three are better still . '[344-kim] [Kim]344-kim quoted the proverb with a meditative cough , looking discreetly earthward . ' True - oh , true . But perhaps that will come . Certainly [those down- country Brahmins]5369-those down- country brahmins are utterly useless . [I]344-kim sent gifts and monies and gifts again to [them]5369-those down- country brahmins , and [they]5369-those down- country brahmins prophesied . '[344-kim] [A professional]1883-a professional could have done no better . ' And it was not till [I]344-kim remembered [my]344-kim own Gods that [my]344-kim prayers were heard . ' Go back ! [Withdraw]465-withdraw ! '[344-kim] [Kim]344-kim cried . ' Do [we]1890-we eat publicly like dogs ? ' Have [I]344-kim not said an hundred times that [the South]1783-the south is [a good land]1781-a good land ? Here is [a virtuous and high - born widow of [a Hill Rajah on pilgrimage]5384-a hill rajah on pilgrimage]5383-a virtuous and high - born widow of a hill rajah on pilgrimage , [she]5383-a virtuous and high - born widow of a hill rajah on pilgrimage says , to [Buddha Gay]466-buddha gay . ' Who else watched over [thee]868-the lama since [our]1890-we wonderful journey began ? '[868-the lama] [Kim]344-kim 's eyes danced in [his]344-kim head as [he]344-kim blew the rank smoke through [his]344-kim nostrils and stretched [him]868-the lama on the dusty ground . ' Have [I]344-kim failed to oversee [thy]868-the lama comforts , [Holy One]385-holy one ? '[344-kim] ' A blessing on [thee]868-the lama . ' [I]868-the lama have known [many men]5386-many men in [my]868-the lama so long life , and [disciples not a few]5387-disciples not a few . But to none among [men]752-men , if so be [thou]868-the lama art [woman - born]5389-woman - born , has [my]868-the lama heart gone out as it has to [thee]868-the lama - thoughtful , wise , and courteous ; but something of a small imp . '[868-the lama] ' And [I]344-kim have never seen [such a priest]5390-such a priest as [thou]868-the lama . '[344-kim] [Kim]344-kim considered the benevolent yellow face wrinkle by wrinkle . ' It is less than three days since [we]5391-we took [the road]4566-the road together , and it is as though it were a hundred years . '[344-kim] ' Perhaps in a former life it was permitted that [I]868-the lama should have rendered [thee]868-the lama some service . Maybe '[868-the lama] - [he]868-the lama smiled - ' [I]868-the lama freed [thee]868-the lama from a trap ; or , having caught [thee]868-the lama on a hook in the days when [I]868-the lama was not enlightened , cast [thee]868-the lama back into [the river]5005-the river . '[868-the lama] ' Maybe , '[344-kim] said [Kim]344-kim quietly . ' Now , as regards [that woman in [the bullock - cart]5395-the bullock - cart]5394-that woman in the bullock - cart .
